articles.headline: 100-Ton Symbols of a Recovery Still Suspended
articles.snippet: Nine months after Hurricane Katrina, shrimp vessels in Alabama list in trees, many yards from the bayou.
articles.abstract: Nine months after Hurricane Katrina, shrimp vessels in Alabama list in trees, many yards from the bayou.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala., June 7 — To understand a little about this small crustacean of a city nine months after Hurricane Katrina, you have to accept a counterintuitive concept: Boats in the trees.

articles.headline: Decision Time in Detroit
articles.snippet: For G.M. and Ford, buyouts provide a way to reorganize in a more efficient way than if they stuck to the letter of their union contracts.
articles.abstract: For G.M. and Ford, buyouts provide a way to reorganize in a more efficient way than if they stuck to the letter of their union contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 8 — It's crunch time for the United Automobile Workers.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: How Surveillance and Betrayal Led to a Hunt's End
articles.snippet: An informant inside Al Qaeda provided the critical piece of intelligence that led them to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to a Pentagon official.
articles.abstract: An informant inside Al Qaeda provided the critical piece of intelligence that led them to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, according to a Pentagon official.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 —Muhammad Ismael, a 40-year-old Iraqi taxi driver, was standing outside his home in the tiny village of Hibhib on Wednesday evening when something unusual caught his eye.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins, Mark Mazzetti and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Questions Raised on Another Chief's Stock Options
articles.snippet: Accusations of corporate stock option abuse were leveled against Cyberonics, a medical device maker that is no stranger to controversy.
articles.abstract: Accusations of corporate stock option abuse were leveled against Cyberonics, a medical device maker that is no stranger to controversy.

articles.headline: After Long Hunt, U.S. Bombs Al Qaeda Leader in Iraq
articles.snippet: U.S. officials said they expected Al Qaeda to name a successor to Mr. Zarqawi  quickly from among his closest aides.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials said they expected Al Qaeda to name a successor to Mr. Zarqawi  quickly from among his closest aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 — With the two 500-pound bombs that killed Abu Musab al-Zarqawi on Wednesday evening, American forces eliminated Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq and boosted the flagging confidence of American officials and the new Iraqi government as they moved into the fourth brutal year of warfare here.

articles.headline: What Happens if Inflation Is Overstated?
articles.snippet: You don't have to be a conspiracy theorist to conclude that in the last decade, an important part of the Consumer Price Index has been understated.
articles.abstract: You don't have to be a conspiracy theorist to conclude that in the last decade, an important part of the Consumer Price Index has been understated.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMONG some Americans, it is almost an article of faith that the Consumer Price Index understates inflation — there are conspiracy theories about why that happens. After all, holding down the C.P.I. saves the government money in a variety of ways and hurts those with pension or Social Security benefits linked to the index.

articles.headline: Hatred He Bred Is Sure to Survive Terrorist's Death
articles.snippet: While Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death could erode his group's ability to carry out attacks, the insurgency he helped ignite will go on without him, according to officials.
articles.abstract: While Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death could erode his group's ability to carry out attacks, the insurgency he helped ignite will go on without him, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 — By finally eliminating Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the American military and its Iraqi allies have killed the man who put a face on the Iraqi insurgency.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Fails in Attempt to Repeal Estate Tax
articles.snippet: A 57-to-41 vote fell short of advancing the bill that shrinks taxes on inherited wealth. Roll Call
articles.abstract: A 57-to-41 vote fell short of advancing the bill that shrinks taxes on inherited wealth. Roll Call
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 8 — Senate Republicans failed on Thursday to muster the votes needed to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, but supporters of a compromise held out hope for a deal this year that could attract enough Democrats to pass.

articles.headline: 100-Ton Symbols of a Recovery Still Suspended
articles.snippet: To understand a little about this small crustacean of a city nine months after Hurricane Katrina, you have to accept a counterintuitive concept: Boats in the trees.     About two dozen shrimp vessels, some of them 80 feet long and weighing more th...
articles.abstract: To understand a little about this small crustacean of a city nine months after Hurricane Katrina, you have to accept a counterintuitive concept: Boats in the trees.     About two dozen shrimp vessels, some of them 80 feet long and weighing more than 100 tons, list in suspended state amid scrub oak and pine, many yards from the bayou where they belong. Removed from the blue and shoved into the green, their white masts and rigging rise like bleached treetops in a forest.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala., June 7 - To understand a little about this small crustacean of a city nine months after Hurricane Katrina, you have to accept a counterintuitive concept: Boats in the trees.

articles.headline: Decision Time in Detroit
articles.snippet: It's crunch time for the United Automobile Workers.     Union members like Rick Yrlas, a 51-year-old auto worker in Flint, Mich., must decide in the next couple of weeks whether to accept a buyout offer from General Motors, where he has worked for...
articles.abstract: It's crunch time for the United Automobile Workers.     Union members like Rick Yrlas, a 51-year-old auto worker in Flint, Mich., must decide in the next couple of weeks whether to accept a buyout offer from General Motors, where he has worked for 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 8 - It's crunch time for the United Automobile Workers.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Deal Stirrings Help to Lift Tribune Stock
articles.snippet: The Tribune Company says it is sticking to a stock buyback plan, but investors yesterday reacted as if the company might be in play.     Shares of Tribune rose 4 percent on speculation about the company's future after the Chandler family -- its se...
articles.abstract: The Tribune Company says it is sticking to a stock buyback plan, but investors yesterday reacted as if the company might be in play.     Shares of Tribune rose 4 percent on speculation about the company's future after the Chandler family -- its second-largest shareholder -- made public its dissent to the buyback plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company says it is sticking to a stock buyback plan, but investors yesterday reacted as if the company might be in play.
articles.byline: By Richard Siklos and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: AN INSURGENT'S DEATH
articles.snippet: FROM JORDAN TO INFAMY -- Abu Musab al-Zarqawi was something of a phantom to the American military, to the Iraqi people and to those who grew up with him in Jordan.   PAGE A10    MUTED HOPE IN BAGHDAD -- Iraqis battered by daily violence expressed ...
articles.abstract: FROM JORDAN TO INFAMY -- Abu Musab al-Zarqawi was something of a phantom to the American military, to the Iraqi people and to those who grew up with him in Jordan.   PAGE A10    MUTED HOPE IN BAGHDAD -- Iraqis battered by daily violence expressed skepticism that Mr. Zarqawi's death could bring peace to a country where so many live to fight.   PAGE A11    AMERICAN TROOPS IN IRAQ -- American military and government officials say privately that earlier hopes that troop levels could be cut to 100,000 by year's end have proved untenable. Mr. Zarqawi's death is not expected to affect the levels.   PAGE A12
articles.lead_paragraph: FROM JORDAN TO INFAMY -- Abu Musab al-Zarqawi was something of a phantom to the American military, to the Iraqi people and to those who grew up with him in Jordan. PAGE A10

articles.headline: Hatred He Bred Is Sure to Survive Terrorist's Death
articles.snippet: By finally eliminating Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the American military and its Iraqi allies have killed the man who put a face on the Iraqi insurgency.     The question now is how large a blow his death deals to the guerrilla movement he drove to such...
articles.abstract: By finally eliminating Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the American military and its Iraqi allies have killed the man who put a face on the Iraqi insurgency.     The question now is how large a blow his death deals to the guerrilla movement he drove to such bloody extremes.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 - By finally eliminating Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the American military and its Iraqi allies have killed the man who put a face on the Iraqi insurgency.

articles.headline: After Long Hunt, U.S. Bombs Kill Al Qaeda Leader in Iraq
articles.snippet: With the two 500-pound bombs that killed Abu Musab al-Zarqawi on Wednesday evening, American forces eliminated Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq and boosted the flagging confidence of American officials and the new Iraqi government as they moved into the ...
articles.abstract: With the two 500-pound bombs that killed Abu Musab al-Zarqawi on Wednesday evening, American forces eliminated Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq and boosted the flagging confidence of American officials and the new Iraqi government as they moved into the fourth brutal year of warfare here.      But the American officials themselves offered an immediate warning against overstating the impact that the death of Mr. Zarqawi, the most wanted insurgent in Iraq, would have on prospects that American and Iraqi forces can gain the upper hand in the conflict. Among other things, they said they expected Al Qaeda to name a successor to Mr. Zarqawi quickly from among his closest aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 - With the two 500-pound bombs that killed Abu Musab al-Zarqawi on Wednesday evening, American forces eliminated Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq and boosted the flagging confidence of American officials and the new Iraqi government as they moved into the fourth brutal year of warfare here.

articles.headline: Questions Raised on Another Chief's Stock Options
articles.snippet: New accusations of corporate stock option abuse were leveled yesterday, this time against Cyberonics, a medical device maker that is no stranger to controversy.     The company's board approved stock option grants for top executives one evening in...
articles.abstract: New accusations of corporate stock option abuse were leveled yesterday, this time against Cyberonics, a medical device maker that is no stranger to controversy.     The company's board approved stock option grants for top executives one evening in June 2004, a few hours after receiving positive news about the regulatory prospects for a promising product. When trading began the next morning, Cyberonics shares soared, and along with them, the value of the options.

articles.headline: U.S. Approves Use of Vaccine for Cervical Cancer
articles.snippet: Federal drug officials on Thursday announced the approval of a vaccine against cervical cancer that could eventually save thousands of lives each year in the United States and hundreds of thousands in the rest of the world.     The vaccine, called...
articles.abstract: Federal drug officials on Thursday announced the approval of a vaccine against cervical cancer that could eventually save thousands of lives each year in the United States and hundreds of thousands in the rest of the world.     The vaccine, called Gardasil, guards against cancer and genital warts caused by the human papillomavirus, the most common sexually transmitted disease. It is the culmination of a 15-year effort that began at the National Cancer Institute and a research center in Australia, and health officials described the vaccine as a landmark.

articles.headline: How Surveillance and Betrayal Led to a Hunt's End
articles.snippet: Muhammad Ismael, a 40-year-old Iraqi taxi driver, was standing outside his home in the tiny village of Hibhib on Wednesday evening when something unusual caught his eye.     Three GMC trucks, each with blackened windows, rumbled past his home and ...
articles.abstract: Muhammad Ismael, a 40-year-old Iraqi taxi driver, was standing outside his home in the tiny village of Hibhib on Wednesday evening when something unusual caught his eye.     Three GMC trucks, each with blackened windows, rumbled past his home and toward the little house in a nearby grove of date palms that for more than three years had stood abandoned.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 8 - Muhammad Ismael, a 40-year-old Iraqi taxi driver, was standing outside his home in the tiny village of Hibhib on Wednesday evening when something unusual caught his eye.
articles.byline: This article is by Dexter Filkins, Mark Mazzetti and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: What Happens if Inflation Is Overstated?
articles.snippet: AMONG some Americans, it is almost an article of faith that the Consumer Price Index understates inflation -- there are conspiracy theories about why that happens. After all, holding down the C.P.I. saves the government money in a variety of ways ...
articles.abstract: AMONG some Americans, it is almost an article of faith that the Consumer Price Index understates inflation -- there are conspiracy theories about why that happens. After all, holding down the C.P.I. saves the government money in a variety of ways and hurts those with pension or Social Security benefits linked to the index.     But you don't have to be a conspiracy theorist to conclude that in the last decade, an important part of the index has been understated. That is the housing component.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMONG some Americans, it is almost an article of faith that the Consumer Price Index understates inflation -- there are conspiracy theories about why that happens. After all, holding down the C.P.I. saves the government money in a variety of ways and hurts those with pension or Social Security benefits linked to the index.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Fails in Attempt to Repeal Estate Tax
articles.snippet: Senate Republicans failed on Thursday to muster the votes needed to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, but supporters of a compromise held out hope for a deal this year that could attract enough Democrats to pass.     Voting 57 to 41, wit...
articles.abstract: Senate Republicans failed on Thursday to muster the votes needed to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, but supporters of a compromise held out hope for a deal this year that could attract enough Democrats to pass.     Voting 57 to 41, with only a few lawmakers crossing party lines, the Senate was three votes short of the number needed to end debate on the bill, dooming it on procedural grounds. The vote all but killed hopes at the White House and among Republicans on Capitol Hill of eliminating the tax on large estates, which under current law would be phased out by 2010 but would return in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 8 - Senate Republicans failed on Thursday to muster the votes needed to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, but supporters of a compromise held out hope for a deal this year that could attract enough Democrats to pass.
